API Documentation¶

Robot¶

class robot.Robot(sensor, robot_drawing=None)[source]¶

This class represent a Robot with 3 leds (2 at the back and 1 at the front).

Parameters:
  • sensor – Sensor that detect the infrared.
  • robot_drawing – (optional) RobotDrawing object.
centre[source]¶

Return a tuple with X and Y location of the robot’s centre

leds[source]¶

When this property is called, leds position is automatically updated and returned.

Usage:

>>> r = Robot(Sensor())
>>> r.leds
{'front': {'X': 10, 'Y': 20}, 'left': {'X': 103, 'Y': 23}, 'right': {'X': 111, 'Y': 203}}

Note: Since leds position is automatically updated at every call, you should save leds location in a variable (e.g leds = robot.leds)

class robot.RobotDrawing(canvas, rad=10, outline_color='red', fill_color='green')[source]¶

Create a RobotDrawing object, represented by 3 dots on the screen.

Parameters:
  • canvas – Canvas of the application.
  • rad – (optional) Radius of the dots.
  • outline_color – (optional) Outline color of the dots.
  • fill_color – (optional) Fill color of the dots.
draw(leds)[source]¶

Draw three dots on the screen.

Game¶

class game.Game(robot, remote_server_object=None, addr_main_server=None, addr_remote_servers=None, remote=False, name=None)[source]¶

Create a game.

Parameters:
  • robot – Robot object used on the table.
  • remote_server_object – (optional) This object will be copied and used to simulate each other remote RoboTable.
  • addr_main_server – (optional) String representing the ip address of the main RoboTable.
  • addr_remote_servers – (optional) A list containing the address of the other RoboTables.
  • remote – (optional) If true, indicates that the object is a remote server. If false, the initialisation of the screen is performed.
  • name – (optional) Name of the game.

Note: most of the arguments are optionals to facilitate the creation of the remote_server_object (but have to be provided if remote=false).

do_calibration()[source]¶

Draw three crosshairs and then return the calibration’s factors (x_factors and y_factors) using the _calculate_calibration method.

draw_robots()[source]¶

Draw robots on the table.

get_addr()[source]¶

Return the ip address of the server.

Note: the solution was find on Stackoverflow.

is_main_server()[source]¶

Return if the server is the main server.

load_map(path)[source]¶

Load the map.

Parameters:path – Path to the map.
start()[source]¶

Launch the game.

Note: This is the method to override when creating your own game.

stop()[source]¶

Stop the game.

class game.Crosshair(root, canvas, x, y, rad=30, color='red')[source]¶

Create a Crosshair object.

Parameters:
  • root – Main window of the application.
  • canvas – Canvas of the application.
  • x – x location of the Crosshair.
  • y – y location of the Crosshair.
  • rad – (optional) Crosshair’s radius.
  • color – (optional) Crosshair’s color.
delete()[source]¶

Delete the crosshair on the canvas.

draw()[source]¶

Draw the Crosshair on the screen.

get_led(sensor)[source]¶

Draw a crosshair, set and return the location of the led.

Wiimote¶

class wiimote.Wiimote(width_resolution=1024, height_resolution=768, test=False)[source]¶

Create a Wiimote object and connect to the dongle USB.

Parameters:
  • width_resolution – (optional) Width resolution of the sensor
  • height_resolution – (optional) Height resolution of the sensor
  • test – (optional) Only use for test-driven
connect()[source]¶

Connect the wiimote to the dongle Bluetooth.

disconnect()[source]¶

Disconnect the wiimote to the dongle Bluetooth.

get_leds()[source]¶

Return a list of the location of leds detected.

(e.g [{‘X’: 10, ‘Y’: 20}, {‘X’: 103, ‘Y’: 23}, {‘X’: 111, ‘Y’: 203}, {‘X’: 121, ‘Y’: 13}])

Note: If the location of a led is not detected, X and Y equal -1.

Network¶

class network.Network(addr=None)[source]¶

Create a Network object.

get(action=None, addr=None)[source]¶

Get data from other table.

Parameters:action – Action name (e.g get_irs, is_ready...).

Note: You need to override this method if you want to implement your own action.

Usage:

>>> n = Network()
>>> n.get('10.4.9.11', 'get_irs')
{'front': {'X': 10, 'Y': 20}, 'left': {'X': 103, 'Y': 23}, 'right': {'X': 111, 'Y': 203}}
get_leds()[source]¶

Return a list of the location of leds detected.

(e.g [{‘X’: 10, ‘Y’: 20}, {‘X’: 103, ‘Y’: 23}, {‘X’: 111, ‘Y’: 203}, {‘X’: 121, ‘Y’: 13}])

Note: If the location of a led is not detected, X and Y equal -1.
